title: 111_s455
content: The Act is titled the "Five-Star Generals Commemorative Coin Act" and includes findings. The United States Army Command and General Staff College at Fort Leavenworth, Kansas has served the nation for 127 years, playing a crucial role in educating and training officers in times of war and peace. The college has had a positive impact on battlefields by providing essential skills in battle management, leadership development, and command procedures, contributing to the nation's success in conflicts and preserving its freedoms. The Command and General Staff College (CGSC) has a long and honorable history, serving as the nation's largest and oldest military staff college. It educates officers from all branches of the US Armed Forces, civilian government members, and officers from allied nations. Located in the American heartland, CGSC promotes intellectual curiosity and military excellence in its students. The United States Army Command and General Staff College Foundation, Inc. is dedicated to promoting excellence in faculty and students, educating citizens about the service of military officers, and fostering pride in military leadership. It is a nongovernmental organization reliant on member funds, donations, and grants. The Foundation supports the CGSC through funding from members, donations, and grants. It is currently engaged in its first capital campaign to support the CGSC. Notable Five-Star Generals who attended or taught at the CGSC include Douglas MacArthur, George C. Marshall, Henry Arnold, Dwight D. Eisenhower, and Omar Bradley. Douglas MacArthur, a distinguished soldier and strategist, served for 61 years. He led forces in World War I, was Chief of the Army General Staff, and Military Advisor to the Philippines. Recalled to duty in 1941, he defended the Philippines and famously declared, "I shall return." General Douglas MacArthur led forces to defeat the Empire of Japan, directed successful reconstruction efforts, and served as the first commander of United Nations Forces during the Korean War. He was the son of General Arthur MacArthur and had a military career that included teaching at the Field Engineering School and serving in various leadership roles. General Douglas MacArthur, who was appointed Secretary of State in 1947, had a distinguished career in public service, serving as a leader, tactician, strategist, and statesman. He was regarded as one of the most talented staff officers in the United States Army during World War I and achieved recognition as one of America's greatest military leaders during World War II. As chief strategist of World War II, he played a key role in directing the Allied Powers to victory. General Douglas MacArthur, appointed Secretary of State in 1947, had a distinguished career as a statesman and military leader. He was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for his role in the European Recovery Program and served as Secretary of Defense for a year. Henry H. "Hap" Arnold, a General of the Army, is the only officer in US history to hold the ranks of General of the Army and General of the Air Force. Henry H. "Hap" Arnold, a graduate of West Point in 1907, received pilot training from the Wright brothers in 1911. He became a strong advocate for air power and achieved numerous flying records, including the first delivery of US mail by air. Arnold's contributions in World War II revolutionized battles with massed air power, dominating the skies and restricting enemy ground mobility. Dwight D. Eisenhower, General of the Army, had a distinguished career in public service, reaching top military and civil leadership positions in the US. During World War II, he led the invasion of North Africa and defeated German forces on the continent as Commander in Chief, Allied Expeditionary Force. In 1944, he served as Supreme Allied Commander. Dwight D. Eisenhower, as Supreme Allied Commander in 1944, led the invasion of Europe and commanded the largest military forces in history. He played a key role in developing NATO and later became the 34th president of the United States. Omar N. Bradley, General of the Army, was a distinguished military leader known for his exceptional leadership, tactical skills, and educational contributions. He developed the officer candidate program at the Infantry School, commissioned over 45,000 leaders for combat forces in World War II, and successfully commanded various military units during the war, including defeating German forces in North Africa and Sicily. Omar N. Bradley reached the peak of his career as a field commander by leading the 12th Army Group in the liberation of Europe with the largest number of American soldiers under his command. He later became the Army Chief of Staff and the first Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. Additionally, he attended the CGSC at Fort Leavenworth from 1928 to 1929. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury shall mint and issue $5 gold coins, $1 silver coins, and half dollar clad coins in specific quantities and compositions to commemorate the Five-Star Generals' attendance and graduation from the CGSC. The coins minted under this Act shall weigh 11.34 grams, have a diameter of 1.205 inches, and be legal tender. They will also be considered numismatic items. The design of coins minted under this Act will be specified. Design requirements for coins minted under this Act include portraits of Generals George C. Marshall, Douglas MacArthur, Dwight D. Eisenhower, Henry "Hap" Arnold, and Omar N. Bradley, along with specific inscriptions and designations. The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with relevant organizations. Design requirements for coins minted under this Act include portraits of Generals George C. Marshall, Douglas MacArthur, Dwight D. Eisenhower, Henry "Hap" Arnold, and Omar N. Bradley, along with specific inscriptions and designations. The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with relevant organizations and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee and the Commission of Fine Arts. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities. Mint facilities will be used to strike proof quality coins and uncirculated quality coins. The Secretary may issue these coins only during a 1-year period starting on January 1, 2013. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins will be sold by the Secretary at a price including face value, surcharge, and cost of designing. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. All sales of coins minted under this Act will include surcharges: $35 for the $5 coin, $10 for the $1 coin, and $5 for the half dollar coin. Surcharges received will be promptly paid to the Command and General Staff College Foundation to support the CGSC. The Foundation will be audited for the amounts received. No surcharge may be included for the issuance of any coin under this Act. The Secretary of the Treasury may issue guidance to limit the number of commemorative coin programs issued in a calendar year to avoid exceeding the annual issuance limitation.
